$DATUM 7732-18-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Using an established procedure 1 a solution of
carboxylic acid (5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (25 mL) was treated with isobutyl
chloroformate (816 mg, 6.0 mmol) and Et3N (505 mg, 5 mmol). After
stirring for 30 minutes at room temperature, 1-dodecanethiol (1.11 g, 5.5
mmol), Et3N (505 mg, 1.0 equiv.), and DMAP (31 mg, 0.25 mmol) were added
successively and the resulting mixture stirred for 70 minutes at room
temperature. The reaction was quenched by addition of H2O (25 mL) and
extracted with ethyl acetate (2 × 50 mL). Combined organic phase was
washed with brine and dried with MgSO4. Purification by flash column
chromatography on silica gel or recrystallizations in hexanes or
EtOAc/hexanes (2 : 98 v/v). S-Dodecyl
(S)-2-(((benzyloxy)carbonyl)amino)-3-phenylpropanethioate (1a)3 .
Following the general procedure A and purification by column
chromatography over silica gel column (CHCl3/hexanes, 1:1 v/v). Compound
1a as a white crystalline solid, yield: (294 mg, 96%). Rf 0.11 (1:4, v/v
EtOAc : hexanes). Mp 77-78 °C (lit. 78.5-80 °C);3 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3)
δ 7.34-7.23 (m, 8H), 7.14-7.12 (m, 2H), 5.16 (d, J= 8.8 Hz, 1H), 5.09 (s,
2H), 4.71 (q, J= 7.2 Hz 1H), 3.11 (ABq, 7.1 Hz, 5.6 Hz 2H), 2.86 (t, J=
7.2 Hz, 2H), 1.61-1.47 (m, 2H), 1.26 (m, 18H), 0.88 (t, J= 6.8 Hz, 3H);

29.5(6), 29.5, 29.3, 29.2, 29.1, 29.0, 28.8, 22.7, 14.1; IR νmax 3343,
1739, 1687, 1215, 1259, 1060, 736, 694.

$DATUM 2-(2-(Tridec-1-en-3-yl)disulfanyl)benzo[d]thiazole (5). A solution of 4a
(643 mg, 3.0 mmol)) in chloroform (8 mL) was added, dropwise, to a well
stirred suspension of 2,2'-dithiobis(benzothiazole) (1.097 g, 3.3 mmol)
in chloroform (45 mL). The addition was performed over a period of 15-30
min and the reaction mixture was stirred until completion. The solution
was evaporated and disulfide was purified by chromatography (hexane/EA
from 100/0 to 95/5) to afford 5 (1.10 g, 96%) as a yellow oil. IR (neat):
3062, 2924, 2852, 1462, 1425, 1005 cm-1. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.85
(d, J=8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.80 (d, J=8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.43 (m, 1H), 7.33 (m, 1H),
5.68 (ddd, J=16.9, 9.7, 9.6 Hz, 1H), 5.18-5.13 (m, 2H), 3.55 (m, 1H),
1.83 (m, 1H), 1.69 (m, 1H), 1.48-1.15 (m, 16H), 0.88 (t, J=6.8 Hz, 3H).
13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ 174.0, 155.4, 136.6, 136.1, 126.5, 124.7,
122.4, 121.3, 119.1, 56.0, 36.7, 32.2, 29.9, 29.8, 29.7, 29.6, 29.5,
27.6, 23.0, 14.4. ESIHRMS: calc. for C20H30NS3 [M+H]+ 380.15349, found
380.15331.

$DATUM 2-(2-(Tridec-1-en-3-yl)disulfanyl)benzo[d]thiazole (5). A solution of 4a

stirred suspension of 2,2’- dithiobis(benzothiazole) (1.097 g, 3.3 mmol)

$DATUM Tri-O-methyl-2-deoxythioglucose 1c. To a solution of 2-deoxyglucose
acetate S3 (0.84 g, 3.4 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (30 mL) was added ethanethiol
(0.50 mL, 6.8 mmol) followed by p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (0.13
g, 6.8 mmol). After 3 h, the solution was washed with saturated aqueous
NaHCO3 (50 mL), and the aqueous layer was extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 x 50
mL). The combined organic layers were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated
in vacuo. The resulting yellow oil was purified by flash chromatography
(3:1 to 1:1 hexanes:EtOAc) to afford tri-O-methyl-2-deoxythioglucose 1c

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S,S-Thioacetalization of carbonyl compounds
(general procedure): A mixture of carbonyl compounds (2 mmol), dithiol
(2.2 mmol) or thiol (4.4 mmol) and P2O5/SiO2 (5 mg) was stirred at
ambient temperature. After completion of reaction as checked by TLC, it
was diluted with n-hexane and the catalyst was filtered off. The filtrate
solution (50 ml) was washed with aqueous 10% NaOH (2 x 10 ml) solution
and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated by
rotary evaporator and the crude product was purified through a column of
silica gel (n-hexane:EtOAc, 80:20) to obtain the pure product. Entry 26d,
yield 96%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM solid-supported catalyst, silica support used, reusable catalyst, no
solvent
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Silica gel-supported phosphorus pentoxide: a reusable catalyst for
S,S-acetalization of carbonyl groups under ambient conditions

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization of Aldehydes and Ketones;
General Procedure. A 100 mL round-bottom flask fitted with a condenser
was charged with silica gel (4 g), CH2Cl2 or hexane (20 mL), an aldehyde
or a ketone (2.5 mmol), 1,2-ethanedithiol (2.75 mmol or 5.50 mmol of an
alkylthiol), and p-toluenesulfonic acid (10-15 mg). The heterogeneous
mixture was refluxed under stirring with a magnetic stirrer. Progress of
the reaction was monitored either by TLC analysis or IR spectroscopy.
After complete disappearance of the starting carbonyl compound, the
reaction mixture was filtered through a sinteredglass funnel. The solid
residue was washed with CH2Cl2 (ca. 75 mL), or with EtOAc (ca. 75 mL)
when hexane was used as the reaction media. The solvent was evaporated
under vacuum to isolate the product. In most of the cases the isolated
crude product was found to be pure as indicated by NMR and IR spectra.
However, the impure products were purified utilizing flash column or
radial chromatography using a mixture of EtOAc and hexane. Several
thioacetalization reactions were scaled up to 100 mmol of carbonyl
compounds. Yields of these large scale reactions were comparable to the
yields reported in Tables 1-5. Compound 9. Yield 96%. IR (neat): 3413
(br), 2966, 1674, 1595, 1512, 1463, 1431, 1269, 1206, 1120, 1031, 730
cm-1. 1H NMR: δ = 1.19-1.24 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 6 H), 2.48-2.62 (q, J = 7.4
Hz, 4 H), 3.87 (s, 3 H), 4.89 (s, 1 H), 5.93 (br s, 1 H), 6.80-7.04 (m, 3
H). 13C NMR: δ = 14.32 (2 CH3), 26.33 (2 CH2), 52.28, 55.93, 110.01,
113.88, 120.73, 132.25, 145.29, 146.78.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM green chemistry (- reagent)
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A simple and efficient heterogeneous procedure for thioacetalization of
aldehydes and ketones
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Ali, Mohammed Hashmat; Gomes, Maria Goretti
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2005), (8), 1326-1332

$DATUM Ethyl 3-O-Acetyl-2-azido-4-(benzyloxycarbonyl)amino-2,4,6-trideoxy-α

-D-galactofuranosyl-(1→
3)]-2-azido-6-Obenzyl-2-deoxy-1-thio-D-galactopyranoside (5): Imidate 29
(123 mg, 0.088 mmol) and ethane thiol (196 μL, 2.65 mmol) were dissolved
in CH2Cl2 (4.42 mL). This solution was treated with 60 mg of preactivated
4Å MS and was stirred for 30 min. The solution was then cooled to 0 °C
and treated with TMSOTf (3.19 μL, 0.018 mmol). After stirring for 1 h at
0 °C, the mixture was quenched with NEt3 (0.2 mL) and concentrated under
reduced pressure. The crude product was purified by silica chromatography
(15:85 to 20:80 EtOAc/hexanes) to give thioglycoside 5 (107 mg, 0.085
mmol) in 96% yield as a 1:1 anomeric mixture. Ethyl

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2-Aminobenzoates 6a-n and 2-Aminothiobenzoates
7a-i; General Procedure. A mixture of N-(2-aminobenzoyl)benzotriazole 8
(1.0 mmol), alcohol (1.2 mmol) or thiol (1.2 mmol), and DMAP (0.122 g,
1.0 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was stirred for 6-12 h (6) or 4-6 h (7) at
r.t. After the completion of the reaction, the solvent was removed under
reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography to
afford the desired product. Phenyl 2-Aminobenzoate (6a). S-Ethyl
2-Amino-5-iodobenzothioate (7i). Eluent: EtOAc-hexane, 1:3; yellow solid;
yield: 0.295 g (96%). mp 76-78 °C. IR (KBr): 3421, 3319, 1628 cm-1. 1H
NMR: δ = 8.16 (s, 1 H), 7.50 (d, J = 10.0 Hz, 1 H), 6.48 (d, J = 10.0 Hz,
1 H), 5.85 (br s, 2 H), 3.05 (q, J = 10.0 Hz, 2 H), 1.36 (t, J = 5.0 Hz,
3 H). 13C NMR: δ = 192.3, 147.3, 142.3, 138.4, 120.8, 119.3, 75.8, 23.5,
14.8. MS (EI): m/z = 307.0 [Mm/z]. HRMS-MALDI: m/z [M + H]+ calcd for
C9H11INOS: 307.9606; found: 307.9621.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Step 6.
N-(6-(tert-butylthio)-7-methoxyquinazolin-4-yl)benzo[d]thiazol-5-amine:
To a solution of
N-1,3-benzothiazol-5-yl-6-iodo-7-(methyloxy)-4-quinazolinamine (2.1 g,
4.5 mmol), 2-methyl-2-propanethiol (483 mg, 5.35 mmol), Et3N (1.9 mE,
13.4 mmol) in DMF (5 mL) was added Pd(Ph3P)4 (516 mg, 0.45 mmol). The
reaction mixture was stirred at 90°C for 1 h. Most ofDMF was removed in
vacuo. The crude material was triturated with MeOH. The red solid was
filtered and washed with Et2O to provide the title compound. Off white
solid, yield 1.7 g, 96%. MS: m/z: 397 [M+H]+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of aminoquinazolines as RIP2 kinase inhibitors

Demartino, Michael P.; Dong, Xiaoyang; Eidam, Patrick M.; Haile, Pamela
A.; Marquis, Robert W., Jr.; Ramanjulu, Joshi M.; Romano, Joseph J.;
Singhaus, Robert R., Jr.; Shah, Ami Lakdawala; Wang, Gren
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2013025958 A1 2013-02-21

$DATUM (2S,3R)-S-ethyl 2-allyl-3-isopropyl-6-(methoxymethoxy)hexanethioate (13).
n-BuLi (19.7 mL, 1.6 M in hexane, 31.5 mmol) was added dropwise to a 0 °C
solution of ethanethiol (2.26 mL, 31.5 mmol) and THF (170 mL) and it was
stirred for 15 mins at same temperature. This suspension was added
dropwise to a solution of 12 (5.1 g, 12.64 mmol) in THF (170 mL) with
rapid stirring. The resulting solution was maintained at 0 °C until TLC
analysis indicated complete reaction (1 h). Sat. NH4Cl (aq) (1 mL) was
added to the reaction mixture and extracted with ethyl acetate (200 mL).
Two layers were separated. Aq. layer was further extracted with EtOAc
(200mL × 2), washed with water, brine before being dried over anhydrous
Na2SO4 and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residue was purified
by silica gel column chromatography (5% EtOAC/hexanes) to give product.
(3.6 g, 96% yield), colorless oil. [α] 20 D = +13.5 (c 0.84, CHCl3); IR
(neat)νmax : 2957, 2929, 1741, 1687, 1472, 1466, 1373, 1265, 1112, 1043,
919 cm-1 ; 1 H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 5.72 (ddt, J= 17.0, 10.1, 6.9 Hz,
1H), 5.05- 4.96 (m, 2H), 4.60 (s, 2H), 3.47 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 3.35 (s,
3H), 2.85 (q, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.69 (ddd, J = 10.5, 6.3, 3.6 Hz, 1H),
2.48-2.10 (m, 1H), 2.25-2.19 (m, 1H), 1.80-1.75 (m ,1H), 1.62-1.54 (m,
3H), 1.39-1.33 (m, 2H), 1.22 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H), 0.90 (d, J = 4.4 Hz,
3H), 0.88 (d, J = 4.3 Hz, 3H); 13 C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ 202.8, 136.0,
116.6, 96.5, 68.1, 56.3, 55.3, 46.7, 33.6, 30.0, 29.8, 24.3, 23.4, 21.2,
18.9, 14.9. HRMS (ESI): m/z: calcd. for C16H30NaO3S : 325.1809, found:
325.1808.

$DATUM Thioester 17a: To a stirred solution of EtSH (12.0 g, 14.0 mL, 194 mmol)
in THF (200 mL) was added BuLi (69.0 mL, 2.4 M in hexane, 166 mmol) at
-78°C. The resultant mixture was warmed to 0°C and stirred at that
temperature for 5 min before a solution of Diels-Alder cycloadduct 13
(25.4 g, 66.2 mmol) in THF (100 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was
stirred at 0°C for 30 min before it was quenched with saturated aq.
NaHCO3 (200 mL). The resulting mixture was extracted with EtOAc (4 × 200
mL). The combined organic phases were washed with brine (2 × 200 mL),
dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, and filtered. After removal of the solvent
under vacuum, the residue was purified by flash column chromatography
with EtOAc/petroleum ether (1:60 → 1:30). Thioester 17a (22.8 g, 96%) as
a colorless oil. 17a: R f = 0.25 (silica, EtOAc:petroleum ether 1:30);
[α]24 D = -33.4 (c = 1.0 in CHCl3); IR (film): νmax = 2953, 2926, 2854,
1742, 1676, 1436, 1358, 1260, 1197, 1052, 1028, 897, 834, 784, 671 cm-1;
1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 4.86-4.79 (m, 1 H), 3.68 (s, 3 H), 3.05
(ddd, J = 10.3, 10.0, 5.9 Hz, 1 H), 2.98 (ddd, J = 10.6, 10.3, 5.3 Hz, 1
H), 2.88 (q, J = 7.4 Hz, 2 H), 2.45-2.29 (m, 2 H), 2.29-2.17 (m, 2 H),
1.24 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 3 H), 0.90 (s, 9 H), 0.13 (s, 3 H), 0.12 (s, 3 H)
ppm; 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 201.68, 174.21, 148.43, 101.45, 51.99,
49.70, 42.24, 32.02, 27.69, 25.66, 23.28, 17.99, 14.77, -4.37, -4.53 ppm;
HRMS (m/z): [M + Na]+ calcd for C17H30O6SSiNa+ 381.1526, found 381.1531.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 3-Ethoxy-3-methyl-1-phenylbut-1-yne (3a);
Typical Procedure 2-Methyl-4-phenylbut-3-yn-2-ol (1a, 80 mg, 0.5 mmol),
EtOH (69 mg, 1.5 mmol), MeNO2 (2 mL), and anhyd CuBr2 (5.6 mg, 0.025
mmol) were successively added to a 5-mL flask, and then the mixture was
stirred magnetically at r.t. for 10 h. The soln was concentrated under
reduced pressure by an aspirator and then the residue was purified by
column chromatography (silica gel) to afford 3a.
3-(Ethylsulfanyl)-3-methyl-1-phenylbut-1-yne (3h), yellow oil, yield 96%.
IR (KBr): 3080, 3058, 2965, 2926, 2859, 2237, 2207, 1449, 1127 cm-1. 1H
NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 1.32 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3 H), 1.69 (s, 6 H), 2.85
(q, J = 7.6 Hz, 2 H), 7.27-7.42 (m, 5 H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ =
14.4, 24.7, 30.9, 38.8, 82.1, 93.6, 123.2, 127.9, 128.2, 131.6. EI-MS:
m/z = 206, 204 [M+], 189, 175, 143, 128, 77. Anal. Calcd for C13H16S: C,
76.41; H, 7.89. Found: C, 76.53; H, 7.76.

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 111F: To a round bottom flask contained 2-fluoro-5-nitrobenzonitrile
(10.07 g, 60.6 mmol) and N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (16.90 ml, 97 mmol) in
DMF (25 ml), was added propane-2-thiol (6.76 ml, 72.7 mmol). The mixture
was stirred rt for 3 h. The reaction was quenched with water. The mixture
was extracted with EtOAc (3×30 ml). The combined organic layer was
filtered through silica gel and concentrated. Purification via flash
chromatography (0-20% EtOAc in Hexanes) affords 111F (13.2 g, 96 % yield)
as a yellow solid. MS (ESI) m/z 223.0 (M+H)+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of macrocyclic amino acid derivatives as factor VIIa
inhibitors useful as anticoagulants
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Mueller, Luciano

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 110-71-4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of Aryl
Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic Thiols. The appropriate
quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a 4 mL vial containing the
aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and NaOtBu (106 mg, 1.10 mmol) in DME
(1.5 mL). The thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial sealed with a
cap containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 4 and 5 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 4 and 5. 2-Methylbutyl 3-methoxyphenyl sulfide (Table
4, entries 10 and 11):47 colorless liquid, yield 91% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ
7.07 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 6.80-6.76 (m, 2H), 6.59-6.56 (m, 1H), 3.67 (s,
3H), 2.84 (dd, J = 12.5 Hz and 5.9 Hz, 1H), 2.64 (dd, J = 12.5 Hz and 7.6
Hz, 1H), 1.60-1.52 (m, 1H), 1.49-1.39 (m, 1H), 1.22-1.11 (m, 1H), 0.91
(d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H), 0.81 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 159.6,
138.8, 129.4, 120.5, 113.7, 110.9, 55.0, 40.2, 34.3, 28.7, 18.8, 11.1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of
Functionalized Aryl Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic
Thiols. The appropriate quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a
4 mL vial containing the aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and LiHMDS or
Cs2CO3 (2.4 mmol) as base, unless otherwise stated, in DME (1.5 mL). The
thiol (1.00 mmol) was then added and the vial was sealed with a cap
containing a PTFE septum. The mixture was heated at the temperature
indicated in Tables 6 and 7 until the aryl halide was consumed, as
determined by GC. Silica gel (0.5 g) was added, and the solvents were
evaporated under reduced pressure. The crude residue was purified by
column chromatography on silica gel with hexane or a mixture of hexane
and ethyl acetate as eluent. Aryl sulfides were isolated in the yields
reported in Tables 6 and 7. Reactions of haloarenes bearing aromatic or
aliphatic hydroxyl groups and LiHMDS as base initially form the
corresponding sulfide with the hydroxyl group protected as the silyl
ether. However the silyl group was removed by treatment with acid (1 N
HCl) prior to the chromatographic purification.
3-(2-Methylbutylsulfanyl)phenol (Table 6, entries 5-6).8 Yellow oil,yield
96% 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 7.04 (t, J = 7.9 Hz, 1H), 6.80 (m, 1H), 6.72 (t, J
= 2.1 Hz, 1H), 6.53 (m, 1H), 5.90-4.20 (bs, 1H), 2.84 (dd, J = 12.3 Hz
and 5.7 Hz, 1H), 2.65 (dd, J = 12.3 Hz and 7.6 Hz, 1H), 1.58 (oct, J =
6.6 Hz, 1H), 1.49-1.40 (m, 1H), 1.22-1.13 (m, 1H), 0.93 (d, J = 6.6 Hz,
3H), 0.82 (d, J = 7.4 Hz, 3H). 13C NMR (CDCl3): δ 155.6, 139.1, 129.8,
120.7, 115.0, 112.5, 40.2, 34.3, 28.7, 18.8, 11.1.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM silica gel used
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM A General, Efficient, and Functional-Group-Tolerant Catalyst System for
the Palladium-Catalyzed Thioetherification of Aryl Bromides and Iodides
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Fernandez-Rodriguez, Manuel A.; Hartwig, John F.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Journal of Organic Chemistry (2009), 74(4), 1663-1672

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for the Coupling of Aryl
Bromides and Iodides with Aliphatic and Aromatic Thiols. The appropriate
quantity of stock solution A or B was added to a 4 mL vial containing the
aryl bromide or iodide (1.00 mmol) and NaOtBu (106 mg, 1.10 mmol) in DME

$DATUM Geranylpyridyldisulfide (17): To a stirred solution of geranyl thiol2
(500 mg, 2.9 mmol) in methanol (8 mL) was added dipyridyldisulfide (1.9
g, 8.82 mmol) and stirred at r.t. After 2 h, the resulting yellow
solution was concentrated and purified by chromatography over silica gel
(eluent: hexanes) to afford geranylpyridyl disulfide 221 (789 mg, 96 %)
as colorless oil. 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 1.57 (s, 3H), 1.64 (s,
3H), 1.66 (s, 3H), 1.93-1.97 (m, 4H), 3.50 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 2H), 5.04 (m,
1H), 5.27 (t, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 7.05 (dd, J = 4.8 Hz, J = 7.6 Hz, 1H),
7.62 (dt, J = 1.5 Hz, J = 8.0 Hz, 1H), 7.74 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H), 8.44
(dd, J = 1.4 Hz, J = 4.7 Hz, 1H); 13C-NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 16.4,
17.7, 25.7, 26.3, 36.9, 39.5, 117.9, 119.5, 120.3, 123.8, 131.7, 136.7,
142.3, 149.5, 160.9; ESIHRMS Calcd. for C15H21S2N1 [M+H]+: 280.1188,
found 280.1177

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-614-CAS-29052090
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 96
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 121-44-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: General Procedure for Disulfide Syntheses for
2a-d. Methanethiosulfonate 3 (β-anomer or β-enriched) was dissolved in
dry dichloromethane (15 mL). Triethylamine (221 μL, 1.59 mmol) was added,
and the resulting solution was cooled to 0 °C. A dilute solution of
ethanethiol (39.7 mL, 0.04 M, 1.59 mmol) was added dropwise with stirring
over 40 min. The reaction mixture was allowed to warm to room temperature
and was stirred for 2 h. Volatile materials were removed in vacuo, and
the residue was purified by column chromatography. Elution with
hexane/ethyl acetate 9:1 furnished 2. Further elution with hexane/ethyl
acetate 7:3 allowed isolation of pure samples of the unreacted R-anomer
of 3 in the cases of 3a and 3b. Ethyl
2,3,4,6-Tetra-O-benzyl-β-D-glucopyranosyl Disulfide 2a. 3a (1.25 g,
estimated β-content 1.59 mmol) gave β-2a (0.78 g, 79% based on β-3a) as a
white solid: Ethyl 2,3,4,6-Tetra-O-acetyl-β-D-glucopyranosyl Disul fide
2c. 3c (1.0 g, 2.2 mmol) gave β-2c (0.930 g, 96%) as a white solid: mp
100-102 °C; [α]24 D -178 (c 1.0, CH3OH); IR (KBr, disk) 3031 (C-H), 1728
(C=O) cm-1; 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3, COSY) δ 1.30 (t, 3H, SCH2CH 3, J =
7.2 Hz), 2.00, 2.03, 2.04, 2.07 (4 × s, 12H, OAc), 2.79 (m, 2H, SCH
2CH3), 3.73 (ddd, 1H, H-5, J(H-5,H-4) = 7.8 Hz, J(H-5,H-6) = 4.8 Hz,
J(H-5,H 6′) = 2.4 Hz), 4.15 (dd, 1H, H-6, J(H-6,H-6′) = 12.3 Hz, J(H-
6,H-5) = 2.4 Hz), 4.22 (dd, 1H, H-6′, J(H-6′,H-6) = 12.3 Hz, J(H-6′,H-5)
= 4.8 Hz), 4.51 (pt, 1H, H-2), 5.09 (m, 1H, H-4), 5.25 (d, 1H, H-1,
J(H-1, H-2) = 8.4 Hz), 5.24 (pt, 1H, H-3); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, DEPT,
HMQC) δ 14.2 (SCH2 CH3), 20.5, 20.6, 20.7 × 2 (CH3CO), 34.0 (SCH2CH3),
62.0 (C-6), 68.0 (C-4), 69.1 (C-2), 73.8 (C-3), 75.9 (C-5), 88.0 (C-1),
169.2, 169.4, 170.3, 170.6 (C=O); MS-ES+ m/z (%) 871 (10) (2M+ + Na), 447
(100) (M+ + Na); HRMS-ES calcd for C16H24O9S2H [M+H]+ 425.0940, found
425.0936. Anal. Calcd for C16H24O9S2: C, 45.27; H, 5.70. Found: C, 45.57;
H, 5.86.

$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: Thioacetalization and Transthioacetalization;
General Procedure To a stirred mixture of a carbonyl compound (1 mmol) or
an acetal (1 mmol) and alkyl thiol (2.2 mmol) or ethane dithiol (1.2
mmol) in CH2Cl2 (10 mL), activated NaHSO4·SiO2 (200 mg) was added at r.t.
The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of
the reaction, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate was concentrated.
The residue was subjected to column chromatography over silica gel and
the column was eluted with EtOAc-hexane (1:4) to afford pure thioacetal.
The spectral and analytical data of the unknown compound are given below.
Compound 2g, yield 96%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Studies on novel synthetic methodologies. Part 39. Simple, mild and
efficient thioacetalization and transthioacetalization of carbonyl
compounds and deprotection of thioacetals: unique role of thiols in the
selectivity of thioacetalization
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

Gurram
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2005), (2), 250-254

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM The compound 4d: General Procedure for the Organocatalytic Sulfa-Michael
Addition to alpha,beta-Unsaturated Ketones: All the reactions were
carried out in undistilled toluene without any precautions to exclude
water. In an ordinary test tube equipped with a magnetic stirring bar,
9-amino(9-deoxy)epi-hydroquinine (10-20 mol %) and D-N-Boc phenylglycine
(20-40 mol %) as the chiral counter-anion were dissolved in 0.8 mL of
toluene. The solution was stirred for 20 minutes at room temperature to
allow the formation of the catalytic salt A. After addition of
alpha,beta-unsaturated ketones 2 (0.2 mmol), the mixture was stirred at
the appropriate temperature for 10 minutes. Then thiol 1 (0.24 mmol, 1.2
equiv.) was added in one portion, the tube was closed with a rubber
stopper and stirring was continued for the indicated time. Then the crude
reaction mixture was diluted with hexane (2 mL) and flushed through a
short plug of silica, using hexane/Et2O 1/1 as the eluent. Solvent was
removed in vacuo, and the residue was purified by flash chromatography to
yield the desired product. The reaction was carried out at rt for 116 hr
using 20 mol % of catalytic salt A following the general procedure. The
title compound was isolated by column chromatography (hexane/Et2O =
70/30) in 96 % yield and 94 % ee. The ee was determined by HPLC analysis
using a Chiralpak AD-H column (80/20 hexane/i-PrOH; flow rate 0.75
mL/min). [alpha 20 D] = -188.0 deg (c = 1.0 in CHCl3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Enantioselective Aminocatalysis: New Reactions and New Directions
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Carlone, Armando
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM (2008), (20140701), No pp.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: N-Fmoc-L-leucyl-L-tert-leucine methyl ester
(3) In a dry 50-mL, two-necked, round-bottomed flask was charged with
MoO2Cl2 (5.0 mg, 0.025 mmol, 5 mol %) in anhydrous CH2Cl2 (5 mL). To the
above solution of catalyst,Fmoc-L-leucine (176 mg, 0.5 mmol in 5 mL of
CH2Cl2) was added at ambient temperature followed by addition of benzoic
anhydride (170 mg, 0.75 mmol in 5 mL of CH2Cl2). A solution of methyl
L-tert-leucinate (80.2 mg, 0.6 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added after 60
min. The resultant reaction mixture was stirred for 8 h and then quenched
with cold, saturated aqueous NaHCO3 solution (20 mL). The aqueous layer
was separated and extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 15 mL). The combined organic
extracts were washed with brine, dried over MgSO4, filtered, and
evaporated. The resultant crude product was purified by column
chromatography (EtOAc/n-hexane, 1/4) on silica gel to furnish 216 mg (90
% yield) of the pure di-peptide.
2-(9H-Fluoren-9-yl-methoxycarbonylamino)-4-methyl-pentanethioic acid
S-tert- butyl ester Data: 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) 7.77 (d, J = 7.6, 2H),
7.61 (t, J = 7.6, 2H), 7.40 (t, J = 7.4, 2H), 7.31 (d, J = 7.4, 2H), 5.09
(d, J = 9.0, 1H), 4.82-4.34 (m, 3H), 4.25 (t, J = 7.0, 2H), 1.72-1.64 (m,
3H), 1.47 (s, 9H), 0.96 (s, 3H), 0.95 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3)
201.46, 155.71, 143.95, 143.77, 141.34, 127.69, 127.05, 125.09, 119.97,
66.99, 59.69, 48.19, 47.25, 42.27, 29.78, 24.77, 23.10, 21.69; IR
(CH2Cl2) 3431 (m), 3225 (m), 2989 (s), 2871 (s), 1955 (m), 1725 (s), 1681
(m), 1491 (s), 1448 (s), 1381 (s), 1351 (s), 1298 (s), 1119 (s), 1041
(s), 934 (s), 917 (m), 844 (s); MS (ESI) 425 (M+, 100); TLC Rf 0.46
(EtOAc/hexane, 1/20).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES

$DATUM B] 3,5-Diethoxy-4-methylsulfanyl-benzaldehyde To a suspension of sodium
hydride (2.62 g, 60.0 mMol, 2.0 eq.; 55% free-flowing powder moistened
with oil) in DMF (50 mL) under Ar was added carefully methanethiol (2.88
g, 60.0 mMol, 2.0 eq.). After 15 min, a solution of
4-bromo-3,5-diethoxy-benzaldehyde (8.2 g, 30.0 mMol, 1.0 eq.; prepared
according to J. Am Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 8033-8038) in DMF (30 mL) was
added, and the reaction mixture stirred overnight. The mixture was
acidified to pH 2 by addition of a solution of 1 M HCl and extracted with
ethyl acetate (3 x 100 mL). The combined organic phases were dried over
MgSO4, the solvent removed by evaporation under reduced pressure and the
crude material purified with column chromatography on silica eluting with
heptane/ethyl acetate (1:1) providing 6.9 g (96%) of the title compound.
3,5-Diethoxy-4-methylsulfanyl-benzaldehyde, yield 6.9 g (96%) 1H NMR (300
MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.50 (t, J= 7.0 Hz, 6H), 2.50 (s, 3H), 4.18 (q, J= 7.0 Hz,
4H), 7.02 (s, 2H), 9.88 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 14.66,17.50,
64.88, 105.71,122.00,135.90, 159.54, 191.31. MS: 240.9 [M+H]+
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of benzoxazole, oxazolopyridine, benzothiazole and
thiazolopyridine derivatives as somatostatin receptor modulators and
antidiabetic compounds

$DATUM Intermediate 42 3,5-Diethoxy-4-methylsulfanyl-benzaldehyde. To a
suspension of sodium hydride (2.62 g, 60.0 mmol, 2.0 equiv; 55%
free-flowing powder moistened with oil) in DMF (50 mL) under Ar was added
carefully methanethiol (2.88 g, 60.0 mmol, 2.0 equiv). After 15 min, a
solution of 4-bromo-3,5-diethoxy-benzaldehyde (8.2 g, 30.0 mmol, 1.0
equiv; prepared according to S. P. Dudek, H. D. Sikes, C. E. D. Chidsey
J. Am Chem. Soc. 2001, 123, 8033-8038) in DMF (30 mL) was added, and the
reaction mixture stirred overnight. The mixture was acidified to pH 2 by
addition of a solution of 1 M HCl and extracted with ethyl acetate (3 ×
100 mL). The combined organic phases were dried over MgSO4, the solvent
removed by evaporation under reduced pressure and the crude material
purified with column chromatography on silica eluting with heptane/ethyl
acetate (1:1) providing 6.9 g (96%) of the title compound. 1H NMR (300
MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.50 (t,J= 7.0 Hz, 6H), 2.50 (s, 3H), 4.18 (q,J= 7.0 Hz,
4H), 7.02 (s, 2H), 9.88 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (75 MHz, CDCl3): δ 14.66, 17.50,
64.88, 105.71, 122.00, 135.90, 159.54, 191.31. MS (ISP): 240.9 [M+H]+.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Preparation 19: Preparation of
2-ethylthio-3-ethoxycarbonyl-4-(naphthalen-1-yl)-1H-pyrrole. 19-1)
Preparation of ethyl[(4-methylphenyl)sulfonyl]methylcarbonochloride
imidothioic acid. 6.22g(100 mmol) of ethanethiol and 200mg of
triethylamine were dissolved in 30ml of carbon tetrachloride and cooled
to 0°C. To the above mixture was added 13.35g(100 mmol) of sulfuryl
chloride slowly. The reaction mixture was stirred for 30 minutes and the
solvent was removed. The resulting residue was dissolved in 15ml of
tetrahydrofuran. 23.4g (120 mmol) of TosMIC in 15ml of tetrahydrofuran
was added slowly to the above mixture. Reaction was carried out for 2
hours under stirring. The solvent was removed to give the title compound.
28g (Yield 96%). FAB(M+H) 292.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of 1-(imidazolylmethyl)-1H-pyrroles as farnesyl transferase
inhibitors
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR

$DATUM 110-54-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM (3R*, 4R*,
18R*)-3-[6-Isobutyryl-9,9-dimethyl-5-oxo-4-(19,19,31,31-tetramethyldioxolan-18-
ylmethyl)cyclohexyl]-3-pentamethyldisilylpropionic acid S-ethyl ester
(26). To a solution of ethanethiol (28 μl, 0.382 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (3.8 mL)
was added Me3Al (378 μL, 0.382 mmol, 1.01 M in n-hexane) at 0 °C. The
mixture was stirred at the same temperature for 25 min and at room
temperature for 10 min. Then again the mixture was cooled down at 0 °C
and 25 (100 mg, 0.191 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (1 ml) was added. The mixture was
stirred at the same temperature for 40 min, followed by the addition of
saturated aqueous potassium sodium tartrate (2 mL), and stirred at room
temperature. After 60 min, AcOEt (5 mL) was added to the mixture followed
by the addition of water (5 mL). The organic layer was separated, and the
aqueous phase was further extracted twice with AcOEt (20 mL). The
combined organic layer was washed with water and brine, dried (Na2SO4),
and concentrated to give aresidue which was purified by silica gel flash
chromatography (AcOEt/hexane, 1/20) to give 26 (107 mg, 0.183 mmol; 96%)
as a colorless oil. 1H NMR (500 MHz, C6D6) δ 4.13 (d, J = 10.4 Hz, 1H),
2.95-3.00 (m, 3H), 2.75 (dd, J = 5.0, 5.0 Hz, 1H), 2.59-2.72 (m, 2H),
2.14 (dd, J = 10.4, 14.7 Hz, 1H), 1.90-1.96 (m, 1H), 1.75-1.83 (m, 2H),
1.66 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 1.38-1.44 (m, 1H), 1.40 (s, 3H), 1.39 (s, 3H),
1.26 (s, 3H), 1.18 (s, 3H), 1.17 (d, J = 6.7 Hz, 3H), 1.13 (s, 3H), 1.12
(d, J = 6.7 Hz, 3H), 1.03 (s, 3H), 1.02 (dd, 7.3, 7.3 Hz, 3H), 0.23 (s,
9H), 0.23 (s, 3H), 0.20 (s, 3H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, C6D6) δ 205.4, 199.5,
195.3, 116.6, 107.8, 81.4, 80.4, 48.7, 45.3, 39.8, 37.4, 36.3, 33.3,
32.4, 30.1, 29.9, 29.7, 29.7, 28.0, 26.4, 24.5, 24.0, 21.5, 20.7, 16.0,
-0.1, -0.6, -1.3; IR (neat, cm-1): 1693; EI-MS m/z 511 (M+- TMS), 541
(M+- i Pr), 584 (M+); EI-HRMS Calcd for C27H49O5SSi2 (M+- i Pr) :

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
Pentacarbonyl[1-(ethylthio)pentylidene]tungsten (8a).
Pentacarbonyl(1-ethoxypentylidene)tungsten (7a) (876 mg, 2.00 mmol) in
methanol (5 mL) was added to a stirred suspension of sodium carbonate
(254 mg, 2.40 mmol) in methanol (20 mL) at -40 °C. After ca. 5 min,
ethanethiol (248 mg, 4.00 mmol) in methanol (1 mL) was added dropwise to
the yellow suspension. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h at -40 C
and then quenched by addition of a few drops of 85% phosphoric acid to
give a red solution. Water (10 mL) was added and the product was
extracted with n-pentane (3 x 50 mL). The combined organic layers were
dried over MgSO4 and then concentrated under reduced pressure to give a
13:2 mixture of 8a/8a’(880 mg, Rf = 0.6 in n-pentane, red oil).
Pentacarbonyl[1-(ethylthio)propylidene]tungsten (8b), yield 96%, 8b. 1H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 25 C): δ 3.81 (q, 3J = 7.7 Hz, 2H; 2-H2), 3.01 (q,
3J = 7.6 Hz, 2H; SCH2), 1.36 (t, 3J = 7.6 Hz, 3H; SCH2CH3), 1.30 (t, 3J =
7.7 Hz, 3H; 3-H3). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 25 C): δ 339.7 (Cq, C1), 206.8 and
197.6 [Cq, 1:4 C; trans- and cis-CO of W(CO)5], 52.4 (WdCCH2), 36.8
(SCH2), 14.2 (CH2CH3), 11.6 (SCH2CH3). IR (n-pentane): ν˜ 2066.5 (50),
1957.9 (80), 1951.7 (100), 1938.8 (60) cm-1 (C≡O). MS (70 eV, EI): m/z
(%) 426 (28) [M]+, 370 [M - 2CO]+, 369 (18), 342 (38) [M - 3CO]+, 314 [M
- 4CO]+, 313 (100). Anal. Calcd (%) for C10H10O5-SW (426.1): C 28.17, H
2.37. Found: C 28.45, H 2.39.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM Mixed Thioketal 15. To a solution of ketone 14 (2.18 g, 3.03 mmol) in
CH2Cl2 (25 mL) were added EtSH (8.0 mL) followed by Zn(OTf)2 (220.0 mg,
0.61 mmol). The resultant solution was stirred at room temperature for 25
h. The reaction mixture was quenched with triethylamine and concentrated
under reduced pressure. Purification by column chromatography on silica
gel (50-90% ethyl acetate/hexanes) afforded mixed thioketal diol (1.62
g). To a solution of the above diol (1.62 g) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) were added
2,2-dimethoxypropane (9.0 mL) and camphorsulfonic acid (160.9 mg, 0.69
mmol). The resultant solution was stirred at room temperature for 2.5 h.
The reaction mixture was quenched with triethylamine and concentrated
under reduced pressure. Purification by column chromatography on silica
gel (0-20% ethyl acetate/hexanes) afforded mixed thioketal 15 (1.75 g,
96% for the two steps) as a colorless oil. [α]21D +41.7 (c 0.27,
benzene); IR (film) 2935, 2870, 1454, 1372, 1094, 736, 697 cm-1 ; 1H NMR
(500 MHz, C6D6) δ 7.29-7.07 (m, 10H), 4.39 (d, J = 11.9 Hz, 1H), 4.29 (s,
2H), 4.28 (d, J = 11.9 Hz, 1H), 4.17 (dd, J = 7.7, 4.8 Hz, 1H), 3.93-3.89
(m, 3H), 3.87 (dd, J = 11.2, 5.6 Hz, 1H), 3.65 (ddd, J = 9.4, 6.7, 6.7
Hz, 1H), 3.58 (dd, J = 112, 9.4 Hz, 1H), 3.47 (dd, J = 9.8, 4.8 Hz, 1H),
3.29 (dd, J = 9.8, 7.7 Hz, 1H), 3.22 (ddd, J = 9.4, 9.4, 5.6 Hz, 1H),
2.82 (ddd, J = 11.5, 9.3, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 2.37-2.18 (m, 5H), 2.04 (ddd, J =
11.9, 4.5, 4.5 Hz, 1H), 2.06-2.02 (m, 2H), 1.86-1.75 (m, 4H), 1.44 (s,
3H), 1.25 (s, 3H), 1.16 (t, J = 7.51 Hz, 3H); 13C NMR (125 MHz, C6D6) δ
138.93, 138.91, 128.6 (x 2), 128.53, 128.48 (x 2), 128.0 (x 2), 127.8 (x
2), 127.7, 127.6, 98.4, 93.2, 82.8, 79.5, 79.0, 78.5, 75.2, 74.0, 73.37,
71.2, 70.9, 63.5, 35.6, 32.3, 30.0, 29.5, 29.1, 22.8, 19.3, 19.2, 15.0;
HRMS (FAB) calcd for C34H46O7SNa [(M+Na)+] 621.2862, found 621.2867.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 4-Methoxyphenyl Phenyl Sulfide (3a); Typical
Procedure Cs2CO3 (325.8 mg, 1.0 mmol), CuBr (14.3 mg, 0.10 mmol), and L3
(26.6 mg, 0.10 mmol) were added to a 10-mL reaction tube equipped with a
septum. The tube was evacuated and back-filled with N2 and MeCN (2.0 mL)
was added to the mixture at r.t. To the resulting soln 4-iodoanisole (117
mg, 0.50 mmol) was added followed by PhSH (60.6 mg, 0.55 mmol), and the
mixture was heated at 82 °C for 10 h. After complete disappearance of
4-iodoanisole (TLC monitoring), the mixture was allowed to cool to r.t.
The crude residue was directly purified by column chromatography (silica
gel, EtOAc-hexanes). Ethyl 4-Methoxyphenyl Sulfide (3h)28 , Colorless
oil. Rf = 0.30 (hexanes). IR (neat): 2960, 2926, 2834, 822, 623 cm-1. 1 H
NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 1.16 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 3 H), 2.74 (q, J = 7.2 Hz,
2 H), 3.69 (s, 3 H), 6.74-6.76 (m, 2 H), 7.24-7.26 (m, 2 H). 13 C NMR
(100 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 14.71, 29.88, 55.38, 114.57, 126.59, 133.22,
158.92. HRMS: m/z [M]+ calcd for C9H12OS: 168.0609; found: 168.0600.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM Ullmann reaction
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE

thioethers catalyzed by a diol-copper(I) complex

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Synthesis (2010), (1), 79-84

$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 100A: (2-Bromo-4-nitrophenyl)(ethyl)sulfane To
3-bromo-4-fluoronitrobenzene (7.05 g, 32.0 mmol) and ethanethiol (2.6 mL,
35.2 mmol) in DMF (20 mL) was added potassium carbonate (4.87 g, 35.2
mmol). The reaction mixture was heated to 60°C overnight. After cooling,
the mixture was filtered over celite and washed with ethyl acetate. The
combined filtrate and washings were concentrated. The residue was
redissolved in ethyl acetate and washed with water (3x) and then dried
over sodium sulfate. The filtrate was concentrated and purified by flash
column chromatography to give 100A (8.09 g, 96% yield) as a solid. 1H NMR
(400 MHz, Methanol-d4) δ ppm 1.41 (t, J=7.34 Hz, 3 H) 3.11 (q, J=7.42 Hz,
2 H) 7.45 (d, J=9.05 Hz, 8 H) 8.17 (dd, J=8.80, 2.45 Hz, 7 H) 8.37 (d,
J=2.45 Hz, 7 H).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM chemoselective
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Preparation of phenylglycinamide derivatives useful as anticoagulants
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Zhang, Xiaojun; Priestley, Eldon Scott; Nirschl, Alexandra A.; Zou, Yan
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2006076246 A2 2006-07-20

$DATUM 110-54-3
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM 2R-Methyl-5-phenyl-3R-(trimethyl-silanyloxy)-pent-4-enethioic acid
S-ethyl ester: BuLi (400 mL, 2.62M in hexanes, 1.05 mmol, 2.29 equiv) was
added dropwise to a –78 °Csolution of ethanethiol (112 L, 1.51 mmol, 3.29
equiv) and THF (6.0 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a 0 °C
ice bath upon completion of addition and maintained at 0 °C for 15
minutes. A solution of 184 (200 mg, 0.46 mmol, 1 equiv) in THF (5.0 mL)
was added slowly with rapid stirring. The resulting solution was
maintained at 0 °C until TLC analysis indicated complete reaction (1
hour) and then diluted with 1:1 hexanes/EtOAc (30 mL each). The mixture
was washed with 0.5 M NaOH (aq, 30 mL) twice followed by one wash with
brine (30 mL). The resulting organic layer was dried (Na2SO4) and
concentrated to give 210 mg of a light yellow oil. The oil was purified
by flash chromatography (10% EtOAc/hexanes) to provide 141 mg (96%) of
thioester as a colorless oil
2R-Methyl-5-phenyl-3R-(trimethyl-silanyloxy)-pent-4-enethioic acid
S-ethyl ester, yield 141 mg, 96% [α]D 23 = -91.8 (c 2.0, CHCl3); 1H NMR
(400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.45-7.20 (m, 5H), 6.55(d, J = 15.7 Hz, 1H), 6.11 (dd,
J = 15.7, 7.3 Hz, 1H), 4.50-4.45 (m, 1H), 3.0-2.77 (m, 3H), 1.28 (t, J =
10.7 Hz, 3H), 1.10 (d, J = 7.0 Hz, 3H), 0.11 (s, 9H); 13C NMR (100 MHz,
CDCl3) δ 202.1, 136.5, 131.7, 129.8, 128.5, 127.7, 126.5, 75.9, 55.4,
23.1, 14.8, 14.0, 0.1; IR (film) 3027, 2965, 2932, 2875, 1686 cm-1; Exact
mass calcd. for C17H26O2S1Si1Na1 (M+Na+): 345.1321; found: 345.1323
(ES+).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Synthesis and Confirmation of the Absolute Stereochemistry of the
(-)-Aflastatin A C9-C27 Degradation Polyol
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Evans, David A.; Trenkle, William C.; Zhang, Jing; Burch, Jason D.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 68-12-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: 2-thioetherbenzaldehyde general procedure
2-nitrobenzaldehyde (33 mmol) and K2CO3 (37 mmol) were dissolved in dry
DMF (50 ml) under a nitrogen atmosphere. The thiol (35 mmol) was then
added at room temp, while stirring at a suitable rate to control the
exothermic reaction and the mixture was stirred at 80°C for 16 hour. The
mixture was cooled at room temp., H2O (200 ml) was added and the mixture
was extracted with MTBE/pentane (1:1). The organic layers were washed
with aq. sat. NH4Cl solution and brine, dried with MgSO4, and the
solvents were distilled under reduced pressure. The crude product was
purified by bulb-to-bulb distillation or column chromatography
(Silicagel, Pent/Et2O). 4-(tert-butyl)-2-(tert-butylthio)benzaldehyde
Yellow oil, 96% yield. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ 10.71 (d, JHH = 0.84
Hz, 1H), 7.90 (d, JHH = 8.20 Hz, 1H), 7.65 (d, JHH = 2.00 Hz, 1H), 7.55
(ddd, JHH = 8.20 Hz, JHH = 2.00 Hz, JHH = 0.84 Hz, 1H), 1.36 (s, 9H),
1.28 (s, 9H); 13C NMR (100 MHz, CD2Cl2): δ 193.4 (CH), 157.9 (C), 137.7
(CH), 137.4 (C), 136.7 (C), 128.0 (CH), 127.1 (CH), 47.6 (C), 35.4 (C),
31.1 (CH3), 31.1 (CH3).
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Hydrogenation of aldehyde and ketone groups with tetradentate
amino/imino-thioether based ruthenium complexes
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Santoro, Francesco; Saudan, Lionel; Saudan, Christophe
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2012084810 A1 2012-06-28

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME310 STEP1

$DATUM Pd(dppe)-Catalyzed Reaction of 1a with n-PrSH. To a DMF-d7 solution (0.5
mL) of 1a (18.9 mg, 0.10 mmol) and 1,3,5- trioxane (4.5 mg, 0.050 mmol)
as an internal standard in an NMR tube were added [Pd2(dba)3•CHCl3] (2.6
mg, 0.0025 mmol) and dppe (2.0 mg, 0.0050 mmol) under a nitrogen
atmosphere. After 5 min, n-PrSH (9.1 mg, 0.12 mmol) and NEt3 (12.1 mg,
0.12 mmol) were added to the NMR tube and the mixture was heated to 60
°C. The reaction was monitored by 1H NMR. Other NMR experiments were
carried out similarly. Isolation of t-BuCtCCH(Me)SPr (2).
[Pd2(dba)3•CHCl3] (25.9 mg, 0.025 mmol) and dppe (19.9 mg, 0.050 mmol)
were added to a solution of 1a (189.1 mg, 1.00 mmol) in dry DMF (5.0 mL)
under a nitrogen atmosphere. After 5 min, n-PrSH (91.4 mg, 1.20 mmol) and
NEt3 (121.4 mg, 1.20 mmol) were added and the mixture was heated to 60
°C. After 3 h, the reaction mixture was purified by column (silica gel
60N, pentane), and the solvent was removed in vacuo carefully to provide
2 (174.7 mg, 0.948 mmol). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3): δ 1.00 (t, 3JH,H =7.5
Hz, 3H, Pr), 1.21 (s, 9H, t-Bu), 1.44 (d, 3JH,H =7.0 Hz, 3H, Me), 1.65
(m, 2H, Pr), 2.59 (m, 1H, Pr), 2.72 (m, 1H, Pr), 3.63 (q, 3JH,H =7.0 Hz,
1H, CH). 13C{1H} NMR (126 MHz, CDCl3): δ 13.63, 22.27, 22.96, 27.42,
29.27, 31.21, 33.32, 79.08, 91.85. HRMS: m/z calcd for C11H2OS 184.1286,
found 184.1282.

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure:
Di-μ-isopropylthiolatotetrakis(1,3-dibenzylbenzimidazolin-2-ylidene)palladium(II)
(5). A mixture of complex (82 mg, 0.1 mmol), 2-propanethiol (0.018 mL,
0.2 mmol), and NaBF4 (27 mg, 0.25 mmol) in CH3CN (12 mL) was stirred at
70 °C for 12 h in a sealed tube. The resulting greenish-yellow suspension
was cooled to ambient temperature, and the solvent was removed under
reduced pressure. Dichloromethane (10 mL) was added to the residue, and
the mixture was filtered through Celite to remove excess NaBF4. The
solvent from the filtrate was removed under vacuum to afford the product
as a pale yellow powder.
Di-μ-isopropylthiolatotetrakis(1-propyl-3-methylbenzimidazolin-2-ylidene)palladium(II),
pale yellow powder, yield 200 mg, 95%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO): 7.74-7.44
(m, 6 H, Ar-H), 7.43-7.38 (m, 10 H, Ar-H), 4.60 (s, 12 H, NCH3),
4.58-4.56 (m, 2 H, NCH2), 4.41-4.36 (m, 6 H, NCH2), 2.17 (m, 2 H, 3J(H,H)
= 6.3 Hz, SCH(CH3)2), 1.84-1.75 (br, 2 H, CH2CH2CH3), 1.66-1.50 (m, 6 H,
CH2CH2CH3), 1.00 (d, 12 H, 3J(H,H) = 6.3 Hz, SCH(CH3)2), 0.71 (t, 12 H,
CH2CH2CH3). 13C{1H} NMR (125.77 MHz, CD2Cl2): 174.1 (s, NCN),
134.8,133.1, 124.7, 124.5, 111.3, 111.2 (s, Ar-C), 50.5 (s, NCH3), 37.9
(SCH(CH3)2), 36.3 (s, NCH2), 27.9 (s, (SCH(CH3)2), 22.4 (s, CH2CH2CH3),
10.6 (s, CH2CH2CH3). 19F NMR (282 MHz, DMSO): -72.28 (s, 10BF4), -72.34
(s, 11BF4). Anal. Calc for C50H70 B2F8N8Pd2S2: C, 48.68; H, 5.72; N,
9.08. Found: C, 48.32; H, 5.63; N, 8.91. MS (ESI): m/z = 1147 [M - BF4]+.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM sealed tube used

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: S-Furfuryl-N-4-(2'-pyridyl)piperazine-1-yl
dithiocarbamate (4a). To the stirred solution of 0.52 g 3 (1.84 mmol) in
10 cm3 anhydrous CH2Cl2 0.30 g 1-(20-pyridyl)piperazine (1.84 mmol) was
added slowly at 0°C and the reaction mixture was stirred for 5 min.
Furfurylmercaptan (186 mm3, 1.84 mmol) and DBU (265 mm3, 1.77 mmol) was
added drop-wise to the stirred reaction mixture at 0°C under N2
atmosphere. After 5 min the reaction was brought to room temperature and
stirring was continued for 2 h. Completion of the reaction was mon-
itored by TLC. Then the reaction mixture was washed with 5% Na2CO3
solution followed by 10 cm3 distilled H2O to keep the reaction mixture
free from liberated benzotriazole, extracted with 2 - 75 cm3 CHCl3, dried
(Na2SO4), and finally, the chloroform layer was concentrated under
reduced pressure. The crude mass thus obtained was purified over SiO2
column using 12-15% EtOAc in n-hexane as eluent. S-n-Propyl-N-benzyl
dithiocarbamate (4i). Yield 95%. Base: DBU, Time: 2h. C11H15NS2. IR
(KBr): ν = 1098, 1502, 2800-2900, and 3402 cm-1; 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3):
δ = 7.35 (m, 5Ar-H), 7.0 (bs, NH), 4.90 (s, NCH2Ph), 3.10 (t, J= 6.6 Hz,
SCH2CH2CH3), 1.70 (m, SCH2CH2CH3), 1.0 (t, J= 6.6 Hz, SCH2CH2CH3) ppm.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM One-pot convenient and high yielding synthesis of dithiocarbamates

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM Monatshefte fuer Chemie (2007), 138(7), 653-658

$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy

of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3

modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of

respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,

pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single

at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2

$DATUM 4

$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 102116-16-5
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 135822-89-8
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-83-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16090593
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME324 STEP1
$RXN

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 102116-16-5
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 172656-81-4
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 942286-55-7
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16090388
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME326 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 102116-16-5
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 254428-47-2
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-89-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16088668
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM 102116-16-5

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-79-6
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16088900
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME330 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-97-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16083880
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 102116-16-5
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 738626-22-7
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-90-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16090162
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated

modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of

respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.

$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.

of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3

pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single

$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number

$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04

$RFMT $RIREG SCHEME341 STEP1

$DTYPE RXN:RCT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 102116-16-5
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951762-66-6
$DTYPE RXN:RCT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 111-31-9
$DTYPE RXN:PRO(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 951343-94-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAS_Reaction_Number
$DATUM 31-254-CAS-16090357
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STEPS
$DATUM 1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):STAGES
$DATUM 4
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):PRO(1):YIELD
$DATUM 95
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 7087-68-5
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 14338-32-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(3):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-72-8
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):RGT(4):CAS_RN
$DATUM 76-05-1
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):CAT(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 603-35-0
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(1):CAS_RN
$DATUM 75-09-2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):SOL(2):CAS_RN
$DATUM 109-99-9
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):EXP_PROC
$DATUM General/Typical Procedure: The allenoic acids 4 were coupled to the
benzyl alcohol units of the SynPhase-PS lanterns grafted with Wang resin
3 using Mukaiyama's reagent and Hunig's base for 4a/b or Et3N for 4c/d.
The direct use of an unmodified Wang resin minimizes the number of
synthetic operations run on solid support. In addition, our strategy
enabled simple trifluoroacetic acid (TFA)-mediated cleavage to release
the carboxylic acid group, a key functional group in our GGTIs. The
phosphine-catalyzed annulation between solid-bound polymer-supported
allenoates 5 and N-tosylimines proceeded smoothly. The allenoates 5a and
5b were treated with N-tosyltolualdimine and 50 mol% of PPh3 (for 5a) or
PBu3 (for 5b) in benzene at 60 °C to provide the polymer-bound
dihydropyrroles 6. Tetrahydropyridines 7 were formed from the reactions
of 5c and 5d with N-tosyltolualdimine in the presence of 50 mol% of PBu3
at room temperature for 2 and 4 days, respectively. The α ,β -unsaturated
enoate functionalities in 6 and 7 were utilized to further increase the
modularity and number of analogs. For example, the Michael additions of
thiols to 6 and 7 using n-butyllithium as base provided 10 and 11,
respectively, which upon TFA mediated cleavage yielded 12 and 13,
respectively, in 77-95% yield (Scheme 2). These two-step sequences
occurred with high diastereoselectivities, providing the pentasubstituted
pyrrolidine 12 and the tetrasubstituted piperidine 13 as single
diastereoisomeric products. Yield 95%.
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):NOTES
$DATUM combinatorial, solid-supported reaction, stereoselective (in stages 2 and
3), Michael addition in stage 3, Et3N can also be used as alternate base
in stage 1, attachment to Wang linker in stage 1, alternate reaction
conditions also shown in stage 2
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):TITLE
$DATUM Inhibitors of protein prenyltransferases
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):AUTHOR
$DATUM Kwon, Ohyun; Tamanoi, Fuyuhiko; Fiji, Hannah; Watanabe, Masaru
$DTYPE RXN:VAR(1):REFERENCE(1):CITATION
$DATUM World Intellectual Property Organization, WO2010014054 A1 2010-02-04
